identificationModule.briefTitle: Medical-economic Evaluation Comparing Intensive Outpatient Monitoring of Neuro-cardiovascular Diseases by Nurses, Doctors and Hospital and Private-sector Pharmacists, Compared to Usual Monitoring.
identificationModule.officialTitle: Medical-economic Evaluation Comparing Intensive Outpatient Monitoring of Neuro-cardiovascular Diseases by Nurses, Doctors and Hospital and Private-sector Pharmacists, Compared to Usual Monitoring.

armGroups.label: Stroke - usual follow-up
armGroups.description: Patient with either primary stroke, recurrent stroke, hemorrhagic, ischemic or Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) with regular follow-up

armGroups.label: Stroke - intensive follow-up
armGroups.description: Patient with either primary stroke, recurrent stroke, hemorrhagic, ischemic or Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) with intensive follow-up

armGroups.label: myocardial infarction - usual follow-up
armGroups.description: Patient who has had a first or recurrent myocardial infarction with usual follow-up

armGroups.label: myocardial infarction -intensive follow-up
armGroups.description: Patient who has had a first or recurrent myocardial infarction with intensive follow-up

interventions.name: Usual follow-up
interventions.description: 2 medical consultations (nurse and doctor) over 24 months

interventions.name: Intensive follow-up
interventions.description: 10 medical visits (nurse, doctor, pharmacist) over 24 months

primaryOutcomes.measure: Cost-utility ratio of the intensive monitoring strategy for each condition (stroke / myocardial infarction)
primaryOutcomes.description: 24-month incremental cost-utility ratio associated with the intensive post-stroke or post-MI follow-up strategy compared to the usual post-stroke or post-MI follow-up strategy, expressed as cost per year of life gained in good health (costs / QALY, score measured using EQ-5D-5L®).

eligibilityModule.studyPopulation: patients with stroke or myocardial infarction

ipdSharingStatementModule.description: Relevant anonymized individual participant data that underlie the results reported in the articles resulting from this clinical trial will be shared to researchers who provide a methodologically sound proposal, to achieve aims of the approved proposal, upon reasonnable request to the principal investigator (Prof. Yannick Béjot, yannick.bejot@chu-dijon.fr). The data will become available after 3 months following the publication of the article and for 5 years.
ipdSharingStatementModule.timeFrame: The data will become available after 3 months following the publication of the article and for 5 years.
ipdSharingStatementModule.accessCriteria: request to the principal investigator (Prof. Yannick Béjot, yannick.bejot@chu-dijon.fr)
